page.title: 14LAND ARMY AT SWAFFHAM PRIOR
page.content: On Saturday June 29th. 1985, thirty women gathered at Swaffham Prior House. They were there to remember their days in the Land Army some forty years ago. This house was their home during the Second World War. Sixty to seventy girls, mostly from the North of England, worked on the land to provide food for the nation. They had a country motto "Dig for Britain." Men used to take the women to work in the fen in lorries. They used to pick potatoes, pull carrots and hoe sugarbeet. They got one pound a week in wages but if they became tractor drivers they got two shillings and sixpence (12.5p) extra. The reunion was the idea of the present owner of the house, Mr. Marshall. He found a list of Land Army rules pasted to one of the attic rooms.
